Description: Cast oblong silver bezel from a finger-ring; pattern of spirals cast in relief.
Curator's comments: This piece lacks close parallels. Petrie originally described it as having ‘an early Greek scroll pattern’ (Petrie 1886, 43); however, its shape, size and material is similar to rings from 6th and 5th century BC Cypriot tombs (British Museum 1969,0401.38 and 1969,0401.174). The spiral motif is known from Egyptian scarabs of the Middle Kingdom onwards, and some Cypriot scarabs dated to the 7th or 6th century BC (British Museum 1894,1101.425). Three spirals were used as a cryptic form of the name of Amun-Ra on Egyptian amulets (Drioton 1957, 11–33), and therefore this piece may be a reinterpretation or misunderstanding of the original Egyptian meaning. Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XX, no. 27)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (QA.02)
